Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer (MS) to Accelerate Studies on Small Molecules and Broaden MS Use at UCSC
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Phillip Crews from the University of California Santa Cruz and colleagues Rebecca Braslau, Theodore Holman, Roger Linington and Scott Lokey will acquire an orbitrap mass spectrometer. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. In an orbitrap instrument there an outer section that acts as an electrode and a coaxial inner spindle-like electrode that traps ions in an orbital motion around the inner electrode. An image of the current is produced and converted to a mass spectrum using mathematical (Fourier transform) methods. This spectrometer will also be used in curricular activities involving students, many of whom are from underrepresented groups.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying metabolites and natural product identification; (b) metabolomics; (c) lipidomics; and (d) organic polymer profiling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer is a high-end instrument that is being used by multiple researchers in a variety of principle disciplines including metabolomics,  natural products, HIV vaccine development, lipidomics, signaling networks that integrate cell growth and cell division, plasticizers for improving the environmental impact of polymers, synthesis and evaluation of cyclic peptide libraries biased toward membrane permeable scaffolds, chemistry of peoroxynitrite with biological targets, and the exploration of metabolomics in marine symbioses using Accurate MS.  The findings, results, and techniques that were developed will likely to make a significant impact on the base of knowledge, theory, and research in these fields.

The project outcomes and significant accomplishments that were enabled by the acquisition of the Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer included 1) the discovery of novel marine natural products with relevance as cancer chemotherapeutics; 2) the characterization of small molecules and modified polymers for research replacing plasticizers in PVC with alternatives that cannot migrate out of the materials and become environmentally hazardous Endocrine Disrupting Compounds (Braslau lab); 3) modification of the surface of PVC to inhibit biofouling; 4) the development of methods for the study of membrane permeability in a class of potential drug molecules called cyclic peptides; and 5) the study of a class of molecules called oxylipins, which are involved in cardiovascular disease. Nine papers have been published based on research that relied heavily on the use of the Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer. In addition to these discoveries and publications, the use of this instrument played a key part in the training of a number of graduate students and post-docs, whose training on the Oribtrap will undoubtedly enrich their careers and scientific pursuits going forward.
